title: Income from Self-employment: Development of an Innovative Life Course Model
abstractText:
Who has a chance to make it in entrepreneurship? This project first pursued this question by considering, conceptually, how entrepreneurship opportunities relate to a person’s experience of social structures across their life course. These ideas have then been tested by modelling how both business start-up and entrepreneur earnings relate to a person’s class-structured opportunity to accrue resources across their life course. We have also tested the effect that a person’s family role has on their ability to apply their resources to exploiting opportunities through entrepreneurship.

Our analysis is highly robust, modelling individual, household and business life course pathways into and through entrepreneurship by drawing on 18 waves of the British Household Panel Survey (1991-2008) using event history analysis and growth curve modelling. 

Our findings suggest strong class based pathways to business start-up and that family roles have a significant effect on both business start-up and earnings. The relationship between entrepreneur earnings and class is less obvious; this may mean that entrepreneurship is a relatively open route of opportunity or it may be that class-based privileges are obscured in our analysis because the wealthy are not motivated to apply their resources efficiently to entrepreneurship. New directions for research are indicated.
